The people working in second career post-retirement jobs probably have a pension in addition to Social Security. Therefore, if the size of their paycheck is less than what they earned before, it's a supplemental income stream and not their livelihood.

Those of us over 50 who lost jobs in the dot com bust of 2000-01, the Post 9/11 Recession of 2001-02, or the current Financial Crisis of 2008-10 have no pensions, Social Security will be bankrupt by the time we are eligible, and our IRA and 401 (k) accounts are in the toilet due to the stock market's gyrations.

Currently, we are unable to find jobs at anywhere near our previous salaries and rampant age discrimination keeps us on the sidelines..

Meanwhile, the discussion that the "official" retirement age of 65 will be jacked higher is frightening.

Where is the government's New Deal/WPA program to create jobs that will tide us over, so we over 50's can earn above minimum wage until we can collect our diminished Social Security and withdraw from our battered retirement savings accounts?
At 67 I'm still working as a life guard which I did as a second job for the last 35 yrs. Not for the money but to see people, feel useful. and get a free gym membership.

Age discrimination is bad for our society in so many ways. Here is one very important one: Young people stay in school longer - to age 25 or so - in order to qualify for jobs. If people are pushed, irrevocably, out of the workforce at age 55, that leaves only thirty years productive life for each person. Now assuming we live to about 85 or so, that is two-thirds of one's life as a "dependent."

This is not sustainable. We would have to raise taxes A LOT to accommodate a society with a minority of workers and majority of dependents. European societies do this with high taxes and a strong safety net, as well as a "leisure is good" ethic. We in the US with our work ethic and low taxes and less of a safety net are going to have to create jobs for everyone who wants and can work at one, and this includes the elderly. Otherwise, it's time for sky-high taxes to support all the dependents.

People get a sense of purpose from working. They may not want to work full-time and they may want to intersperse with periods of leisure, but most people want to work. Sitting on the porch sipping lemonade, or playing golf, or low-level volunteer work like stuffing envelopes or counter sales gets old fast.

Seniors work, some because they must; others for the social context or for the sense of fulfillment. This article was about that and about choice. The right to choose is the gift of working at what you select for the joy of it.

Always in the early years and in the middle years of our lives were entirely occupied striving. We worked at what we wanted to become, once there, worked at the expectations of what we had become. We had time for nothing else if we wanted to do justice to the task before us. We of course did just that.

Then when our lives reach the senior shelves we found it to be nothing but that. It is on that shelf we are able to see out and view an altogether new perspective open to us. It is the horizon of our choosing. Ours but to make that selection we choose and proceed on our way. This is what the Gray One in the article is about.

It is also what I am about. My horizon was different than that of Linh Pham in the article. We are not different in age, we are different in circumstance. He yet has his health, I do not. Nonetheless we have both made the choice this time of our respective lives offer us.

That choice for both of us was undertaking to do, within the capacity we could do, something that would be both satisfying and fulfilling. His is to do have the social contact from the work he is doing and supplementing his pension. Mine is to sit home and write about what is keeping me home and unable to do many things.

Mine is fulfilling because not only is it a choice available to me at my age 74, it is one the uniquely allows me to hope I make a difference with what I do with an otherwise devastating illness, Alzheimer’s disease (AD). I enjoy writing; thank God I can yet do so. My payback is the satisfaction of doing something that might be helpful.

Not many of us can still write and talk about it in full sentences with this disease. In that way AD, hateful as it is, my particular brand comes in a very palatable gift package.

Both Linh Pham and I are doing what we choose and I will say for him as I can say for me, we are finding more happiness from it than we ever thought possible.

Friedman says it means the deficit, education, infrastructure, immigration, and of course global warming. Have you ever been to his house by the way? Holy mama.

Anyway we're not worried about Americans as long as they don't blow up the world which is always a possibility. Or, almost as bad, attack Iran which makes the price of oil skyrocket. Please continue to put Valium in the plastic cups and plates we sell them. And don't let them measure your irises! /s

A tragic bit of satire which only a liberal & perhaps a strapped conservative or two can appreciate. I'm afraid Sen. Kyl & former half-Gov. Palin, along with most other Republican "leaders," wouldn't know what you were getting at. Unfortunately, Americans suffering under nonsensical Republican obstructionism get the joke. We get it because the joke's on us.

And the laughs keep coming. Just look what's been reported in the last 24-hour news cycle:

The "liberal" Republican Sen. Scott Brown from Taxachusetts blocked a vote on extending jobless benefits, which expired at midnight, because "We just found out today, or late yesterday, that we were even going to talk about this." Right. Brown had no idea the Congress was leaving two million Americans destitute. Whose fault is that? I knew about it, & so did most of those two million Americans about to lose their benefits. Why, I'll bet the Chinese embassy staff knew about it, too.

Meanwhile over at the White House, the President appointed Friend of the Banksters Tim Geithner to "negotiate" with Republicans on tax breaks for the wealthy. Never mind that those tax breaks will force us to borrow more from China, my money (what little I have) is on Geithner's caving to the wealthy immediately if not sooner. That should make for some very cheery Chinese embassy cables.

And those elections the Chinese found so comical? The Chinese and most Americans probably think they were over a month ago. But they're not. In Alaska, the state asked a court to expedite a suit brought by Joe Miller, who lost the election by thousands of votes but who has brought what the state calls as "unfounded" challenge against the results. In Minnesota, they're still counting votes in the governor's race, with the Republican candidate challenging a ridiculous number of election board decisions. Monday he claimed that a totally blank ballot was a vote for him. Our quaint little elections really are laughable.

Oh, and that civil war we had a century-and-a-half ago? Some Americans can't quite get over it just yet. Throughout the South, the Times reports, they're planning "secession balls" & other hoopla to celebrate the states' seceding from the Union. Oh, glory. I lived in a mixed-race neighborhood (not so easy to find in these parts), but that doesn't stop one of my lovely white neighbors from flying the Confederate flag. Wonder how a rebel flag would fly in China?

In fact, about the only news from the last 24-hour cycle that might have the Chinese embassy staffers scratching their heads is the Supreme Court's concern for the "horrendous conditions" (Justice Breyer's words) in California jails. The Supremes didn't seem to agree on what to do about the overcrowding in California jails, but at least they cared. It's likely the Chinese would wonder what the fuss was all about. It's encouraging to know that sooner or later (usually later) we try to get some things right here.

This is a spot on critique of our country today. But I disagree on one thing - your statement that we are too politically polarized. Instead, on the critical economic and foreign policy issues we face, we are not polarized enough.

In particular, we have one side, the Republicans, who aggressively fight for exactly what they believe in. On the other side, the Democrats too often give into the incessant message from the conservative media that the Democrats need to sacrifice their core beliefs in favor of timid centrism and "bi-partisanship." As a result, our political system has moved consistently rightward, even while reality shows the need to move leftward.

So, over the past 30 or so years we have enacted massive deregulation of financial, banking, credit card, and housing industries. We progressives knew that such deregulation would result in the spectacular meltdown that occurred over the past couple of years. Unfortunately, too many Democrats were unwilling to aggressively fight such deregulation and so we have essentially conceded the argument to the Republicans even though they are wrong.

On Iraq, Republicans did whatever they could to invade, which was a disastrous waste of lives and resources. Progressives knew it was a bad idea, but too many Democrats wanted to appear to be "centrists" and so voted for it.

On the economy, Republicans fought every effort at stimulus. Democrats knew that significantly more stimulus was needed, but instead they cut back in an effort to appear centrist.

And Republicans have been working to undermine the critical role of government in our society. Progressives know the importance of government in developing and maintaining infrastructure, regulating industry, protecting our environment and public health, and providing a safety net. But too many Democrats have declined to offer a full-throated defense of government as they were concerned that such an approach would undermine their appearance of centrism.

The result of all of this is that way too few people have been fighting for the bold progressive change that we need to restore our economic strength here at home and our moral strength abroad. As progressives, we need to start demanding that the Democrats do better in fighting back against the conservative viewpoint that is undermining the fabric of our society.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

They've got the goods to blackmail or prosecute anyone they like, maybe using trumped up or contrived evidence...who knows? How do you protect yourself or contradict fabricated electronic evidence? He underwent extreme chemo and a stem cell transplant in '09 using the cells they harvested from him earlier.  This past June he had no cancer cells in his bone marrow but struggles w/hospital and insurance he's not had any treatment since August.  His IGA is 470 at present with WBC and platelets normal YET he is unable to get out of bed 3-4 times a week.  He is prescribed fentanyl patches (two 100mgh every two days) and oxycodone for breakthrough pain.  He is also taking paxil and Acyclovir.  Any suggestions for his well-being?  His is 51-years old and we have an 8-year old son.  Thank you. Sharon
So where are the official solutions?
